I dont like Starbucks, never really have. But its an interesting thought exercise If you were given 85 million signing bonus plus an even sicker compensation package, what changes would you make to prove you were worth it? Myself, my forte is in making services and products undeniably great, and letting quality drive the business side. Not to the exclusion of shrewd business strategy and tactics, but I just put the priority on having something great that people want, and letting that be the flywheel. So for me, Id finally accept the incredibly common perception that Starbucks actual coffee is mediorceburnt. Weve seen others publicly and with humility accept and fix that... see McCafe, DPZ, CMG, etc. For those who say you cant make that change! I say you cant expect big changes unless you make changes. For those who say the old is good enough, I point to the stock performance as proof its not. Id be the best quality and go with a nicer but more broadly appealing taste profile. As SBUX, wed have the scale and resources to get the very best while still benefitting from scale. Im not sweating about margins in the first wave of this transformation because frankly a drink that you can charge a food price for suggests margin not be a problem over time. Second Id embrace some tech. People are kind of over the myth that you need a slow paced barista teasing out your drink for five minutes. CafeLux and Nespresso have shown you can get 90 of great coffee or cold drinks without lifting a finger. Id seek to take the best of learnings from those and apply them to a faster service model. Maybe that means the barista role is to focus on the part only they can do, and do best, but spares them from the other 90. Thats still TBD, but the goal of pumping out the actual drinks, cold or hot, WAY faster is not negotiable. In parallel wed have some kind of highly mediamentionable value choices. Perhaps not the 99 cent coffee that every pundit thinks they were the first to think of, since it would only be reinforcing the oldbad taste and also trading short term traffic surge which isnt the problem for weaker reputation and perception. But maybe some quick and easy 3 buck options that are enough to generate broad public knowledge. The taste and speed have to be newsworthy upgrades. The value options must also generate a buzz, but should be aligned with supporting not undermining the first two priorities. There would be more phases, but the emergency mission would be whole new supply and taste, combined with huge efficiency boost by automating that which can be. That phase alone probably justifies yesterdays 20 billion move.

While this is one of the most consequential weeks for trading in all of 2024, as this is the week that the MAG7 all report earnings (the last time in calendar year 2024 they do so), it's also the end of October trading and rebalancing of the books. Many institutions sell stocks to log in the entry, even if they intend to buy back later. Once we get past tomorrow, Oct 31st, we enter a more bullish period for the market as we approach the window for the Christmas rally period as well. With such a heavy separation of the market's view of Election Day, that's the next big hurdle, and one could argue that Ouster wins either way, because in either case you would have either anti-China sentiment (DJT) or a pro-West Coast sentiment (Ouster in San Fran, a district that KH is beholden to, including Sister Nancy P. and her fickle husband). I've seen numerous scenarios run for either candidate winning, and you get wins either way. Either Pete B. as Transportation Secretary may gain even more influence (and already has the back of Ouster), or you get so much anti-China trade sentiment that anyone operating autonomous platforms or even simply ADAS, or even a tractor/combine near a US Military base - none of those will be allowed to have a Chinese-Hesai sensor that can map out the environment. Feel free to counter-point/argue here, I'd enjoy seeing the pros/cons of either side winning, but I think the wins for Ouster balance out no matter who wins.

This will be updated after Q3 10-Q on Nov. 7th. Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 (justified if Ouster proves the delayed sale and new sales growth are locked in).As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Now divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Now factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue (Edit: over 30 times more revenue based on recent MVIS earnings warning for Q3).TTM P/S 7 Fair Value mark of $14.42 is a valuation mark, a starting point, and recent trading history shows that this is also a price range that OUST has traded into on good news. If you wanted to be even more conservative in your Fair Value analysis, you could use TTM P/S 5 that puts a more conservative mark at $10.30 but that is still above the current OUST trading range.
Sold 75%, back to about 40%

Considering that OUST Fair Value is at least $10.30 as the mark for TTM P/S 5, and at $14.42 for TTM P/S 7, I think you're quite safe at half of the latter, and at 30% off the former. For these higher risk stocks that are quite different from my normal holdings of boring REITs that pay distributions and rarely move much in stock price, OUST is at a very low point in its valuation curve. Could OUST go a lot lower and present an even better Entry Point than today? Sure, any stock could. The super-volcano under Yellowstone National Park could blow up today, kill off 1/3 of the United States, crash our stock markets to half or below current value, and every stock in America is on sale. Chances of that happening today? Yahoo wouldn't let me post all the zero's to the right of the decimal point before entering the 1, for something like one quadgoogle(th) of a percent chance (I think that would be 400 zero's after the decimal). We don't invest based on those odds. It's just easier to say "It's safe to buy under $10" and not even list the 30 cents above $10 that still count towards Fair Value. Why it just doesn't matter - Ouster's customer-driven company holds tremendous potential, except just like that Super-Volcano, any of their 850 customers could "erupt" in a good way, and expand their fleet.(edit) and FYI, my normal MO is to buy at least a dozen or more blocks of stock when it's beaten down, just to ensure I dollar-cost average as I catch the Falling Knife. It's a technique.

Your statement is slightly confusing, but let me help you out and detail this a bit. Technically, "last quarter" was 3rd Quarter since we're in 4th Quarter now, and that Q3 is not public, no 10-Q to review yet, data is not yet auto-loaded here in Yahoo stats. Debt was "paid off" in August, mid-Q3, after Q2 books were closed and not in Q2 10-Q, so not in Yahoo Statistics here nor any other brokerage house's auto-data pull from published reports. That was a verbal statement and part of the Q2 Earnings Conf Call, that the CFO said the debt was paid in August. That was now over 2 months ago, so we don't yet know complete picture yet, because it's within Ouster's ability to easily start new debt of a small amount that would not have to be publicly reported, and even that could be an arrangement in this ongoing quarter, which would not hit the upcoming reported Q3 10-Q. Just being detailed and precise on this, because the "truth" changes by the day, and by the reports you can see, and what verbal information the CFO will say in the upcoming call on Nov 7th.As for "where" on 10-Q to see Debt, see the Consolidated Balance Sheet, Liabilities, in the section for non-current liabilities.

I have a few questions about the Ouster OS series technology vs the coming DF technology.It seems the differentiators for the OS series are: 1) VCSEL laser emitter. 2) Optics which define the focal length of the target.3) SPAD photon detector.4) Micro-optical system. (not exactly sure what this means other than processing fpga/uP/etc..)The information that I can find on the DF sensor basically is the same as above, but significantly includes two other items:5) Global Shutter.6) Digital Flash.I do not have experience with Lidar, but I do know something about camera design and RTL logic design in FPGA's.  Global shutter (as opposed to a rolling shutter) means all the pixels are exposed to the image (the light) at the same time.  This is why they don't have motion artifacts and yes, it's a big deal.  Digital Flash would burst broadcast VCSEL laser emitters simultaneously, which you can see would work well with a Global shutter.  So I have two basic questions and I'm not even sure if anyone will know, but please shout out if you do.1) All of the OS series device datasheets have a specification for "Rotation Rate" in the range of 10 or 20 Hz.    What is this talking about?  2) Are the differences between the OS and DF series of devices summed up in the Global Shutter and Digital Flash capabilities or am I missing an important item?Lastly, question #2 is not meant to say "That's not enough"..  actually that's a huge deal, but I am still curious for the answer.thanks,david

Regardless my opinions on you, let's break down where you're wrong on valuation. Pre-profitability Growth stocks such as OUST and all other LiDAR companies in the Western world, should be valued using Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio analysis, with TTM P/S 5 as the most conservative mark. This is age-old wisdom from the 1930s, after the 1929 crash when Stock Market Analysts had to get away from Speculation. If you don't have profits, you can't factor P/E, PEG nor FWD P/E either. P/S can be factored, however. It's a rear-view mirror approach, forcing the upstart company to "prove it" with Performance Data. This valuation method results in the safest way to assess value instead of the glossy tri-folds at Investor Conferences, and the speeches that CEOs give. Luminar, in contrast, tries to push their Order Book that include sales projections that don't have signed deals. Ouster instead only bases their future on signed deals in their Booked Orders, making Ouster much more conservative fiscally. This is why you can put more trust in Ouster earnings projections than their peers, and TTM P/S 5 = $10.30 as a minimum Fair Value mark. The current price level around $7 is a safe Entry Point for the stock, even if the 10-Q comes in line at the middle of the earnings range (Fair Value goes up even if they only hit the middle as Y-over-Y would have grown).

Other LiDAR companies have their own problems. Read the online Congressional Research Services report on LiDAR, as they updated it recently. That's the Think Tank in support of our Congress. It may surprise you, to see all the nefarious and foreign ties to the many US LiDAR companies. Luminar has ties to Russian Oligarchs via GVA Capital, and growing Chinese influence to include a Chinese Geely/ECARX executice on the Luminar Board of Directors, and soon after that person joined LAZR's board, they started exploring options to shift LiDAR manufacturing to China. Hesai and all other Chinese LiDAR developers and manufacturers are under orders from the CCP that China's military (PLA) must have full access to LiDAR facilities, to include any foreign companies operating R&D or manufacturing facilities in China (to extract their IP for military use).

Nearly 14 months ago, I first brought up a policy issue that essentially puts government into the business of subsidizing robotization while disincentivizing hiring actual human workers. Case in point has been the California Minimum Wage shift that has elevated to $20/hour now. What many outside California don't realize, is that Silicon Valley pays a lot of money to lobby State Govt and the Governor to elevate wages, because a costly human is the best incentive to buy robots instead.If you want proof, search for this headline:Chipotle Starts Replacing Workers With Robots to Bypass Californias Minimum Wage LawsThere are at least a dozen articles out for this specific issue, and many other companies are going the same route. In the past, at lower Minimum Wage Levels, the cost of buying robots to work in fast food was prohibitive, but not now. Just be aware that Silicon Valley lobbies your own State Governments also (and Governors) to raise Minimum Wage across the entire USA (and this effort is going global).One could argue it's a Chicken vs Egg debate, but in Silicon Valley, the Golden Goose comes from government, to essentially push out low-wage workers while their tech companies get enriched with automation investments and purchases. I'm a huge supporter of what Ouster is doing for Autonomy, but this is one area where California has laid a rotten egg.

How is Ouster different than their peers? Ouster pursued all the Verticals or sectors outside of the Auto Industry primarily, in ramping up sensor development and with their R&D focus over the years. Ouster applied most resources toward what is now the OS Family of Sensors - not Auto OEM grade/sized, but more of a universal option to put LiDAR on as many different platforms as possible. The OS Family is in the Auto Industry, as post-OEM mods such as panel vans, buses, and semi-trucks.The OS Family opened up a wider variety of Use Cases for customers to develop next-gen solutions, and is why Ouster now has hundreds of customers that have experimented with the OS Family.Amazon uses this same approach, and helps explain why Ouster gets great Margins for their sales (up in the 40% Gross Margin range), because Amazon uses Proteus robots in the warehouse to offset personnel costs. In any business, normally the largest cost driver are the personnel costs. This affects the Cost Of Goods Sold (COGS, an acronym to remember). Amazon will gladly pay a premium for an Ouster sensor, to reduce personnel costs. Whereas a fickle Retail Consumer shopping for an Automobile, may not want to use their limited funds to buy an expensive LiDAR add-on option. In addition, the Auto Industry itself is fickle as to what vendors they buy car parts from (just check how your car stereo speakers change year after year, as one example).Ouster is succeeding because it helps lower COGS in multiple industries.

Avea uses FMCW LiDAR. It gets instantaneous velocity without having a need for it to be calculated. It operates at a 1550nm wavelength which works better for longer distance because of the longer wavelength.As for disadvantages: Those lasers are significantly more expensive. Rain and fog degrade that wavelength 4 to 5 times more than the 905nm wavelength. It is 95% worse in snow. It also consumes about 10 times more power and generates more heat.FMCW LiDAR signal is also analog so it needs to be converted to digital whereas Ouster's LiDAR comes out of the sensor as a digital signal. Ouster's signal needs the computer to compute for velocity but FMCW's instantaneous velocity signal needs to be converted from analog to digital. As computation speed increases whatever advantage FMCW has becomes smaller and smaller but the disadvantages remain the same.Mobileye was working on FMCW LiDAR but recently announced they had quit development of it apparently deciding the disadvantages outweighed the advantages.

Interested in engineering take on 4D LiDAR which includes speed as the 4th dimension.  AEVA touts it and appears to have some of the Daimler business in 2026.  Will our new chip and sensor include a speed calculation?

I don't think ADAS is the answer for propelling LiDAR. I will be blunt - I probably rent as many cars as anyone here on the board, and all the modern vehicles across all price levels with ADAS - are horrid. First thing you do in a new rental - turn off all that ADAS garbage. The "ride experience" is basically an attempt to bring video game controller "shakes" of the steering wheel into the driver's steering wheel. If you change a lane on the highway without using the turn signal - ADAS vibrates your steering wheel, and in some cases it tries to steer against you, then causing reaction/over-reaction as you fight the wheel. Some brands' ADAS are worse than others (worse - I say, because none are "good" and all have enormous flaws). The dashboard electronics are failing also - try to connect with Google or Apple play, and many vehicles have "Error" messages for the dashboard hardware not having the latest software. This is a trending thing for rental car companies btw - having vehicles with electronics that fail their customers, and "Fleet Vehicles" are being requested to come without a lot of this stuff installed on it, but we will see how Auto OEMs respond. So, no - ADAS isn't the answer, it's a failing tool in the auto industry at the moment because of nanny-like actions the car takes against the driver.

Stock Buybacks 101, and why they are done:Reduces Dilution of the stock. This is especially true if the company had a long period of using stock-based compensation in formative years and moving toward profitability there is enough cash to buy them back. Same is true for countering the dilution of prior equity offers or ATM sales of shares.Increases the Earnings-per-share metrics. Fewer Shares Outstanding means EPS calculations become more favorable for quarterly and annual reports, influencing stock analysts who center on the EPS performance.A way to return capital to shareholders, with limited taxation. Often an overlooked aspect of stock buybacks, but shareholders that experience an increased share price are not yet taxed, whereas if the company paid a dividend instead, that would have been taxed.The company finds their stock undervalued. Management knows if the company will meet expectations, yet if the stock price does not reflect either their past performance metrics (P/S and/or P/E), and is not fairly valued for known future performance (PEG), a company would wisely buy back its own shares in anticipation of meeting or exceeding performance that near-guarantees the company buys back shares at a price lower than what it should trade toward later.

Just so you hear this (and I say this a lot in here) -- Ouster's way of bundling is actually not beneficial to them. Sure, it gives a CEO at an Earnings Call a way to parse out a 4-slice pie for Analysts who often don't want diatribe or details, but in reality - LiDAR is so new to the commercial side (even though 20 yrs old for Commercial and 60+ years old for military/NASA, but I digress) - regardless, LiDAR is still so new to most people, that it must be explained like Steve Jobs used to do with early tech talks he held.There are over 20 different NAICS coded Industries that Ouster sells into, and Auto Parts is only one of them. Recommend you look at the way NAICS codes lay out, and SEC SIC codes (OUST files per its SIC code btw), although among all LiDAR centric companies, there's at least 4-5 different SEC SIC codes being used (no consistency, leading to confusion). Since there is technically not a "LiDAR Industry" as a NAICS code nor SEC SIC code, it's just a slang term for now and not official. Same is true for Smart Infrastructure - that's not a NAICS or SEC SIC coded thing, it's just made-up. Back to Steve Jobs - you can make things up, even silly names like "iPhone" and "smartphone" but you must explain to the public what these terms mean. I don't mind Angus trying to get organized, but at the same time - he needs to know when to channel Steve Jobs and talk about all 20+ NAICS industries that OUST sells to, and not hold back.

Ouster diversified their sales into four main verticals: Smart Infrastructure, Robotics, Industrial/ warehouse automation and automotive.There is growth in all four verticals, but the fastest growth is in smart infrastructure. Many sales there are coupled with Ousters software.

Excellent article in Top Speed re the Volvo EX90. The self-driving will then be integrated/upgraded.This method is opposed to Waymo or Cruise which gather data with their respective taxi services.Great strategy in my book.

As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 for proven annual revenue growth and pre-profitability Growth Company:OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue.If you wanted to be even more conservative in your Fair Value analysis, you could use TTM P/S 5 that puts a more conservative mark at $10.30 but that is still above the current OUST trading range.

As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock is now $14.42, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 for proven annual revenue growth as a pre-profitability Growth Company:OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Now divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Now factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue.TTM P/S 7 Fair Value mark of $14.42 is a valuation starting point, and recent trading history shows that this is also a price range that OUST has traded into on good news.

Just a word of both encouragement yet challenge to all those currently holding OUST Long. What's changed since last Quarter? Things have changed for the better. Now? There is real fear out there - of Ouster's competitors, and of the financial Institutions that wrongly guessed as to who would become a successful LiDAR developer and manufacturer. Those Institutions only have themselves to blame - in many cases, they put lower tier Analysts on the task of determining who the best LiDAR companies are, and as often happens, they were fooled by glossy tri-folds and Investor Presentations while the Analyst did not fully understand the Hard Science of the underlying technology - Electro-Optical LiDAR Sensors. As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock is now $14.42, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 for proven annual revenue growth and pre-profitability Growth Company:OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Now divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Now factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue.TTM P/S 7 Fair Value mark of $14.42 is a valuation starting point, and recent trading history shows that this is also a price range that OUST has traded into on good news.
